pageData.text: In this investigation, students will explore the basic principles of human chromosome analysis. They will use simulated chromosomes to create at least two , which are visual, ordered displays of the chromosomes. Students are challenged to determine which genetic disorders, if any, are represented. Before undertaking this investigation, students should be familiar with the general structure of chromatin and chromosomes, and the cell cycle, including the events of mitosis and meiosis.

pageData.text: <button class=glossary-text>Karyotypes</button> are useful tools for examining chromosomal abnormalities. Traditional karyotypes do not have the resolution to see beyond large scale genetic changes, such as missing or extra chromosomes.  However, many chromosomal abnormalities are less obvious, resulting from the translocation, repetition, or deletion of regions of chromosomes which may not be visible in a traditional karyotype.  Newer methods of karyotyping that use fluorescent tags or other visualization techniques can help pinpoint smaller chromosomal changes. These sections can be further analyzed or sequenced to understand the exact makeup of the chromosomes and the genetic causes of various disorders.

This specificity has also opened the door for the development of more targeted therapies to treat genetic conditions. Currently, gene therapies are being developed in which a vector, such as a virus, is used to insert missing genes or functional copies of mutated genes into an individual’s genome. While most of these therapies are in their early stages, they represent a promising new avenue for treating previously incurable genetic diseases.Chromosome set humans.jpg by Prateek Pattanaik is available under CC BY 4.0 at https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Chromosome_set_humans.jpg

pageData.text: Throughout most of the life cycle, human cells have chromosomes existing as . In a homologous pair, both chromosomes have the same genes at the same (locations). Humans typically have a total of 46 chromosomes, a complete set consisting of 22 pairs of (non-sex chromosomes), or , and 1 pair of . However, for reproduction, human (sperm and egg) are created through meiotic division (Figure 1), which produces gametes carrying 23 chromosomes, one chromosome from each homologous pair. During fertilization, the gametes combine, restoring the number of chromosomes to 46. In this way, half of an individual’s chromosomes are inherited from the mother (the maternal component) and the other half from the father (the paternal component).

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram depicting maternal and paternal contributions of autosomes and sex chromosomes to the genetic makeup of the next generation

pageData.text: The study of chromosomes, chromosome abnormalities, and related diseases is called . Many cytogeneticists use to examine the chromosomes. A karyotype is a visual, ordered display of all the chromosomes from a , a body cell that is not a . Karyotypes are created using a photomicrograph (a photo taken with a camera attached to a microscope) of the condensed, duplicated chromosomes that have been arrested in metaphase using colchicine, a drug that inhibits mitosis. The use of colchicine allows the chromosomes to be arrested during a stage in which they can be easily visualized. This step is necessary because in non-dividing cells, chromosomes take the form of long, stringy fibers that bunch together in the nucleus like a cotton ball. During metaphase of mitosis, however, the chromosomes are condensed and visible as separate entities.

After the chromosomes have been arrested, a dye is added to stain them. This results in distinctive banding patterns on the chromosomes; these banding patterns make each pair of chromosomes distinguishable from the others.

The stained chromosomes are then photographed through a microscope. The resulting photo of chromosomes is called a . The chromosomes in a metaphase spread are randomly distributed, so traditionally, the photomicrograph would be printed and the chromosome images cut out to be matched into pairs by size, banding pattern, and centromere position (explained below), and then examined for abnormalities. In modern karyotyping, it is more common to digitally cut and paste the chromosome images, but the method of analysis remains the same.

Chromosomes are classified as one of three types on the basis of the position of the centromere (see Figure 2). Chromosomes with the centromere near the center are . Those in which the centromere lies off-center between the middle and tip of the chromosome are classified as , and chromosomes in which the centromere lies near the tip are classified as . Chromosomes are usually positioned in a karyotype with the shorter arm upwards; this shorter arm is designated . The longer arm is designated .

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: When chromosomes are positioned in a karyotype, the shorter arm (p) is on top, the centromere in the middle, and the longer arm (q) is on bottom.

pageData.text: Normal homologous chromosomes have the same banding pattern, centromere position, arm length, and size. By careful analysis of chromosome morphology, cytogeneticists match pairs of homologous maternal and paternal chromosomes from the . In a , the are displayed in approximately from largest to smallest (1–22), followed by the . Chromosomes are also arranged into groups (A through G) according to common physical features, i.e., size and centromere position. The following table shows how chromosomes are typically grouped based on centromere position within size order. Figure 3 illustrates the relative shapes and sizes of individual human chromosomes.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Drawings of the 22 human autosomes, and the X and Y sex chromosomes

pageData.text: Occasionally during meiosis, are formed with an atypical number of chromosomes (a numerical abnormality). Embryos arising from such gametes typically are nonviable (cannot survive), or they result in an individual with a disorder. Numerical abnormalities result from a failure of homologous chromosomes to separate during meiosis I or when (duplicated chromosome copies joined at the centromere) fail to separate during meiosis II, as shown in Figure 4. This failure to separate is called , and it can occur with any chromosome pair, including the .

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram depicting normal meiosis, with correct distribution of chromosomes to the resulting gametes, and nondisjunction of homologous chromosomes and sister chromatids, resulting in an uneven chromosome distribution

pageData.text: When a gamete with an extra chromosome combines with a normal gamete during fertilization, the result is a zygote (single cell with a nucleus formed by the fusion of the egg nucleus and the sperm nucleus) possessing three copies of the chromosome. This is known as a <button class=glossary-text>trisomy</button> (Figure 5, left). When a gamete lacking a copy of a chromosome combines with a normal gamete during fertilization, the result is a zygote with only one copy of the chromosome. This is known as a <button class=glossary-text>monosomy</button> (Figure 5, right).

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Diagram depicting fertilization with normal and abnormal gametes, resulting in zygotes with trisomy or monosomy

pageData.question: In which chromosome pairs can nondisjunction occur?

options.text: any chromosome pair, except the sex chromosomes

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Nondisjunction can occur with any chromosome pair, including the sex chromosomes.

pageData.question: What is the result of a zygote with only one copy of a chromosome?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Monosomy occurs when a zygote has only one copy of a chromosome.

A cell divides uncontrollably into an abnormal mass of cells.

data.title: Acrocentric
data.content: Describes a chromosome with the centromere located near the tip

data.title: Autosomal chromosome
data.content: Non-sex chromosome; also called an autosome

data.title: Autosome
data.content: Any chromosome that is not a sex chromosome

data.title: Cytogenetics
data.content: The study of chromosomes, chromosome abnormalities, and related diseases

data.title: Gamete
data.content: A reproductive cell containing only half the genetic material necessary to form a complete organism

data.title: Homologous pair
data.content: A pair of chromosomes where each have the same genes at the same locations

data.title: Karyotype
data.content: A visual, ordered display of all the chromosomes from a somatic cell

data.title: Metacentric
data.content: Describes a chromosome with the centromere near the center

data.title: Metaphase spread
data.content: A photograph of stained chromosomes viewed through a microscope

data.title: Monosomy
data.content: Occurs when a gamete lacking a copy of a chromosome combines with a normal gamete during fertilization; result in a zygote possessing only one copy of a chromosome

data.title: Nondisjunction
data.content: The improper separation of either homologous chromosomes in meiosis I or sister chromatids in meiosis II

data.title: p
data.content: The shorter arm of a chromosome

data.title: q
data.content: The longer arm of a chromosome

data.title: Sex chromosome
data.content: A chromosome that participates in sex determination

data.title: Sister chromatids
data.content: Duplicated chromosome copies joined at the centromere

data.title: Somatic cell
data.content: A body cell that is not a gamete

data.title: Submetacentric
data.content: Describes a chromosome with the centromere located off center, between the middle and the tip

data.title: Trisomy
data.content: Occurs when a gamete with an extra chromosomee combines with a normal gamete during fertilization; results in zygote possessing three copies of a chromosome
